posts.post_content:
I'm sick of how all the rats in Magic are black and evil-looking, so this is a godsend for the owner of two adorable pet rats.  
  
I have 20 copies of this guy. I named him püffy.

Posted By: TheZombifier (11/8/2012 9:35:48 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
I don't think people get the point of this guy... he does something that [mind rot](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=mind rot) doesnt do unless you have something like [hypersonic dragon](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=hypersonic dragon) out... you could force the opponent to discard on their turn. At best this guy stalls the board while you get mana or draw into a kill spell for that [loxodon smiter](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=loxodon smiter) they've either been keeping in hand or waiting for. Attacking with drainpipe vermin probably plays into your opponent's game plan, unless its got[rancor](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=rancor) on it. So keeping it on the defensive means that your opponent has to take a chance on whether you want to block with it or not.  
  
He's a turn 1 play that the opponent will either waste removal on before you get the chance to pay for the triggered ability, in which case that [pillar of flame](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=pillar of flame) will no longer be a threat to that [deathrite shaman](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=deathrite shaman) you were holding onto, or something your opponent won't be willing to att... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)

Attacking with drainpipe vermin probably plays into your opponent's game plan, unless its gotrancor on it. So keeping it on the defensive means that your opponent has to take a chance on whether you want to block with it or not.

Posted By: techwitch (11/25/2012 1:52:25 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content: I was ready to compare this to an old favorite of mine, [Insidious Bookworms](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Insidious Bookworms), however the non-random discard really tends to hurt it. I'd still prefer my Bookworms, but this is a cute option for any Rat deck that doesn't mind setting aside a little extra mana to ensure the trigger goes through. The problem with this card over, say, [Ravenous Rats](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Ravenous Rats), however, is that your opponent can better play around the discard and only get rid of the Drainpipe Vermin when it is least hurtful for them.
posts.html:
I was ready to compare this to an old favorite of mine, Insidious Bookworms, however the non-random discard really tends to hurt it. I'd still prefer my Bookworms, but this is a cute option for any Rat deck that doesn't mind setting aside a little extra mana to ensure the trigger goes through. The problem with this card over, say, Ravenous Rats, however, is that your opponent can better play around the discard and only get rid of the Drainpipe Vermin when it is least hurtful for them.

posts.post_content: This is intended to empower re-animator decks: a chump blocker that lets you put monsters like [Teysa, Envoy of Ghosts](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Teysa, Envoy of Ghosts) into your graveyard, so you can pull her out with [Obzedat's Aid](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Obzedat's Aid).
posts.html:
This is intended to empower re-animator decks: a chump blocker that lets you put monsters like Teysa, Envoy of Ghosts into your graveyard, so you can pull her out with Obzedat's Aid.
